reply_context.text: Even if AI surpasses human efficiency to answer any question, humans will still be the ones asking them.

posts.text: should we be worried about embodied AI? maybe. but should we be worried about all scientific inquiry being fully automated by AI in its current liminal form? nah.

reply_context.text: But note that the issue in this hypothetical is separate from automation of science specifically: it is more of a matrix-esque risk of humans being supplanted by an invasive, alien species of embodied AI who supplant humanity generally.

posts.text: But note that the issue in this hypothetical is separate from automation of science specifically: it is more of a matrix-esque risk of humans being supplanted by an invasive, alien species of embodied AI who supplant humanity generally.

reply_context.text: for it to be possible for AI to be "interested" in these questions, they need to encounter these obstacles and/or phenomena. Perhaps someday AI will be embodied in such a fashion that they will meaningfully be motivated by the kind of curiosity that motivates us.

posts.text: for it to be possible for AI to be "interested" in these questions, they need to encounter these obstacles and/or phenomena. Perhaps someday AI will be embodied in such a fashion that they will meaningfully be motivated by the kind of curiosity that motivates us.

reply_context.text: we have reasons to ask these questions because we are embodied. we exist in the physical world and interact with it. we have physical and psychological needs that drive us to find new and better ways of doing things or explaining new and strange things we encounter.

posts.text: we have reasons to ask these questions because we are embodied. we exist in the physical world and interact with it. we have physical and psychological needs that drive us to find new and better ways of doing things or explaining new and strange things we encounter.

reply_context.text: In domains where there are infinite valid questions to be asked, or where space of available questions is constantly changing and is actually a function of how we interact with the world and problems we encounter and hope to solve: the questions we ask are asked for a reason.

posts.text: In domains where there are infinite valid questions to be asked, or where space of available questions is constantly changing and is actually a function of how we interact with the world and problems we encounter and hope to solve: the questions we ask are asked for a reason.

But all of science is not physics. There is no limit to the mathematics that we could invent and ladders of abstractions that we could construct on top of those invented systems. Complex systems like biological domains are constantly changing.

reply_context.text:
There are (I think) two core assumptions baked into my position here. If you disagree with my position, you probably disagree with at least one of these assumptions:

1. The domain of possible knowledge is not finite (but is bounded).
2. Pursuit of knowledge is a motivated task.

reply_context.text:
You're continuing to misunderstand me. It's not that craving knowledge "gets you anything". It's that passion differentiates professional researchers from hobbyists.

If a lab has resources to allocate, they want those to go to people who are focused on that topic, not people who side project it.

posts.text:
You're continuing to misunderstand me. It's not that craving knowledge "gets you anything". It's that passion differentiates professional researchers from hobbyists.

If a lab has resources to allocate, they want those to go to people who are focused on that topic, not people who side project it.

reply_context.text: The idea that just the craving for knowledge would get you anything, is already very far from reality thanks to capitalism. It's a good starting point, and in my opinion a necessity to have in science. In a time where human research is considered a nice little side hobby, this won't be any better.
